DataElement.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Mitoses Per 50 High Power Fields Count Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric representation of the mitoses count per 50 high power fields.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Mitoses Per 50 High Power Fields Count
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting._For each, generally denoting a ratio._A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::50_The area visible under the maximum magnification power of the objective being used in microscopy._The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors. It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors. The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined. Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredName: Per Integer::50 High Power Field Mitotic Count
Property.preferredDefinition: For each, generally denoting a ratio.:A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::50:The area visible under the maximum magnification power of the objective being used in microscopy.:The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors. It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors. The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined. Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.

Concepts.definition: For each, generally denoting a ratio.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
The area visible under the maximum magnification power of the objective being used in microscopy.

The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors.  It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors.  The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined.  Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for TCGA Adrenocortical form and released per approval by T.Lichtenberg. mc 1/4/13

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors. It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors. The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined. Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields._A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors. It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors. The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined. Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: The number of mitoses identified under the microscope in tumors.  It is one of the parameters that determine the grade of malignant tumors.  The method of counting varies, according to the specific tumor examined.  Usually the mitotic count is determined based on the number of mitoses per high power field (40X) or 10 high power fields.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.
